summary: This is an email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney to U.S. Attorney Audrey Strauss regarding a FOIA case (Times v. BOP) where the New York Times is seeking Bureau of Prisons documents related to Jeffrey Epstein. The email conveys a request from Judge Engelmayer for Strauss to reconsider the government's FOIA withholdings in light of the change in administration.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Recipient of the email; Judge Engelmayer requests she review the government's FOIA response regarding Epstein documents.

persons.name: Judge Engelmayer
persons.context: Presiding judge in Times v. BOP FOIA case; expresses skepticism about BOP's document withholdings and requests the U.S. Attorney's Office reconsider its position.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the FOIA requests; his death and related BOP records are at the center of the litigation.

persons.name: Noel
persons.context: One of two BOP employees prosecuted (U.S. v. Noel) for their duties the night of Epstein's death; cited as a basis for withholding documents under FOIA Exemption 7(A).

persons.name: Tortaglione
persons.context: Former police officer and death penalty defendant (U.S. v. Tortaglione) who was briefly Epstein's cellmate; his prosecution is cited as a basis for withholding documents.

connections.description: Judge Engelmayer is making a formal request to U.S. Attorney Strauss regarding the government's litigation position in a FOIA case.
Tortaglione was briefly Epstein's cellmate at the time of an apparent suicide attempt by Epstein.
Noel was a BOP employee on duty the night of Jeffrey Epstein's death.

events.title: Oral Argument in Times v. BOP
events.description: Judge Engelmayer holds oral argument on the New York Times's FOIA lawsuit seeking BOP documents related to Jeffrey Epstein and expresses skepticism about the breadth of the government's document withholdings.

events.title: Change of U.S. Administration
events.description: Change in presidential administration referenced by Judge Engelmayer as a potential reason for the government to reconsider its FOIA response position.

events.title: Epstein's Apparent Suicide Attempt
events.description: Referenced event where Jeffrey Epstein attempted suicide while briefly cellmates with Tortaglione.

keyFacts: The New York Times is suing the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) under FOIA for documents related to Jeffrey Epstein.

BOP is withholding a substantial number of documents under FOIA Exemption 7(A), citing potential interference with two criminal cases: U.S. v. Noel (BOP employees) and U.S. v. Tortaglione (Epstein's former cellmate).
Judge Engelmayer is skeptical of the breadth of the BOP's withholdings and requests U.S. Attorney Audrey Strauss to reconsider the government's position, potentially elevating it to Main Justice.
The change in U.S. Administration in January 2020 is cited as a potential reason for reevaluating the FOIA response.
The document reveals ongoing legal efforts to obtain BOP records concerning Epstein's death and the surrounding circumstances.
